dt: {bc}to toss so as to cause to turn over in the air

dt.t: {wi}flip{/wi} a coin
{wi}flip{/wi} a pancake
{wi}flip{/wi} me the ball
{wi}flip{/wi} one end of the scarf over your shoulder

dt: {bc}to cause to turn and especially to turn over

dt.t: {it}flipped{/it} the car
{it}flipping{/it} the pages of a book

dt: {bc}to move with a small quick motion

dt.t: {wi}flip{/wi} a switch

dt: {bc}to turn (something) on or off with a switch

dt.t: {wi}flip{/wi} on/off the lights

dt: {bc}to change or move through (channels, stations, etc.) quickly

dt.t: {wi}flipping{/wi} channels with the remote control

dt: {bc}to buy and usually renovate (real estate) so as to quickly resell at a higher price

dt.t: He's {it}flipped{/it} three houses for a substantial profit.

dt: {bc}to cause or persuade (a witness) to cooperate in prosecuting a criminal case against an associate

dt.t: … wrote that the … probe seemed to have reached the stage where investigators are in the process of {wi}flipping{/wi} witnesses.

dt: {bc}to make a twitching or flicking movement

dt.t: the fish {it}flipped{/it} and flopped on the deck

dt: {bc}to turn or roll from one side to the other {bc}{sx|turn over||}

dt.t: The crab had {wi}flipped{/wi} onto its back.
The car {wi}flipped{/wi} over.

dt: {bc}to do a {d_link|somersault|somersault} in the air {bc}to do a flip

dt.t: He {wi}flipped{/wi} off the diving board.

dt: {bc}to change from one state, position, subject, etc., to another

dt.t: The job market {wi}flipped{/wi} from hot to cold.
The commercial {wi}flipped{/wi} back and forth between scenes of country life and city life.

dt: {bc}to change or move through channels, pages, etc.

dt.t: He sat on the couch {wi}flipping{/wi} through the channels.
{wi}flip{/wi} to another station
{wi}flip{/wi} through the pages of a magazine

dt: {bc}to cooperate in the prosecution of a criminal case against an associate

dt.t: Before sentencing, two more members defected …. And, soon after receiving his 45-year sentence in May 1989, Leonetti {wi}flipped{/wi}, too.
The patient {it}flipped{/it} out in manic behavior.
She {it}flipped{/it} out when she heard about her son's accident.

dt: {bc}to achieve an outcome or adopt an approach that is opposite to or completely different from what has happened or been done previously

dt.t: Now, having won three of the last nine majors, Mickelson has {wi}flipped the script{/wi} on Woods.
… the chance to {wi}flip the script{/wi}, to go from 0-6 with a chance to finish the second half of the year 5-1, is motivating Nebraska players this week.

If you let your inner critic do all the talking, of course she's going to chip away at your self-esteem. Make a conscious choice to {wi}flip the script{/wi} for the next week and see how dramatically it alters your outlook.

shortdef: to toss so as to cause to turn over in the air; also : toss
to cause to turn and especially to turn over
to move with a small quick motion

dt: {bc}a mixed drink usually consisting of a sweetened spiced liquor with beaten eggs

an act or instance of flipping

dt: {bc}the sound or motion of something flapping loosely
{bc}a sudden reversal (as of policy or strategy)
{bc}a usually electronic device or a circuit (as in a computer) capable of assuming either of two stable states
{bc}a rubber sandal loosely fastened to the foot by a thong

a sudden reversal (as of policy or strategy)

dt: {bc}to hold up the middle finger as an obscene gesture of contempt to

dt.t: {it}flipped off{/it} the other driver

dt: {bc}a cell phone with a hinged body that opens and closes

dt.t: Smith, who was still using a {wi}flip phone{/wi}, was suspicious of his girlfriend's preoccupation with social media, worrying that it would detract from the experience.

shortdef: a cell phone with a hinged body that opens and closes

dt: {bc}the reverse and usually less popular side of a phonograph record
{bc}a reverse or opposite side, aspect, or result

dt.t: the {it}flip side{/it} of deficient saving … is overconsumption

shortdef: the reverse and usually less popular side of a phonograph record
a reverse or opposite side, aspect, or result

dt: {bc}to work as a cook in a fast-food restaurant

dt.t: He got a job {it}flipping burgers{/it} after school.

shortdef: to work as a cook in a fast-food restaurant

dt: {bc}a chart that consists of a series of large pieces of paper which are attached at the top and which are used to present information to an audience by turning over one piece of paper at a time

shortdef: a chart that consists of a series of large pieces of paper which are attached at the top and which are used to present information to an audience by turning over one piece of paper at a time

dt.t: His mother {it}flipped her lid{/it} when she saw what a mess he'd made.

shortdef: to become crazy or very angry
